body:
I think we have to accept that we can never cater perfectly for all use-cases here, and that someone is always going to be surprised whatever behaviour is chosen. I am OK with either strategy, as long as it's clearly documented.

I also have a strawman proposal - maybe mitmproxy shouldn't be doing this at all. Instead, we can provide a script-reload function through a web API, and let users use a tool like [modd](https://github.com/cortesi/modd) instead to get precisely the behaviour they expect. This would also remove one of our trickier dependencies.

The idea of auto-reloading is not so bad (you can reload by simply `touch`ing), but the current implementation is somehow surprising, as it observes the whole directory, while the documentation only mentions the actual script.

@RobbBienert: If @cortesi is fine with either behaviour, I think we'd be more than happy to accept a PR that changes the implementation (and updates the docs)! :smiley:

You've probably seen this already, the place to fix this is [`mitmproxy/addons/script.py#L124`](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/6792cc1de90b02b89da9ae80704ea237c5486e66/mitmproxy/addons/script.py#L124)! ðŸ˜Š
I'm back again and working on the fix -- see pull request #1911

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.title: Hot reloading of multi-module mitmproxy scripts

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
#### Problem Description

I have a relatively large addon written as a package consisting of several modules. One of the modules (`main.py`) serves as the addon entrypoint which I load with the `-s` flag (`mitmdump -s main.py`). The rest of the modules in the package are imported by `main.py`.

I would like mitmproxy/mitmdump to reload my addon completely when any of the addon's modules change (or their mtime changes). So, for instance, when I make a change in modules `foo.py` or `bar/baz.py`, which are used by the module `main.py`, I would like that these changes are automatically reflected in the running mitmdump session.

Is this possible in current mitmproxy? I've seen some hints in old issues that there might be ways to specify which files it should watch but the documentation doesn't seem to mention it and all the code that the issues were referencing is old and doesn't seem to exist anymore.

Can I achieve this, and if yes, how?

#### Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Create a mitmproxy script `main.py`, which imports/depends on `foo.py` and `bar/baz.py` which are located in the same directory.
2. Load `main.py` as a script in mitmproxy/mitmdump via the `-s` flag.
3. Do some changes to `foo.py` or `bar/baz.py`.
4. Observe that `main.py` *did not* get reloaded and the changes are not reflected.

#### System Information
```
â¯ mitmproxy --version

Mitmproxy: 5.2
Python:    3.8.6
OpenSSL:   OpenSSL 1.1.1h  22 Sep 2020
Platform:  Linux-5.4.72-1-lts-x86_64-with-glibc2.2.5
```
